lessons.title: s
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's explore how to make our React apps more interactive.

First, add a button with some text.

Make sure to pick <button>, followed by Click me, and finally </button>.

lessons.title: s - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can add the onClick event handler to handle clicks on the button.

In React, it follows camelCase, so it becomes onClick. This is slightly different from the HTML/JavaScript click handler onclick.

Make sure to pick onClick.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To run JavaScript, we add an embedded expression.

Add an empty embedded expression.

Make sure to pick =, followed by {, and finally }.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To call a function, we need to reference it without parentheses. First, we define an arrow function and assign it to a variable.

We then pass that variable to onClick as a reference, so the function runs when the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick handleClick, followed by handleClick.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also run JavaScript directly inside the embedded expression.

However, it's executed without clicking the button because the function is called immediately instead of being passed as an event handler.

Make sure to pick = followed by { and then console.log("Hi"), }.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
This is usually not what we want. To avoid this, we wrap the code in an arrow function.

The arrow function doesnâ€™t run right away. It waits until the event triggers it. Now, the code will be executed on button click.

Make sure to pick (), followed by =>.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is true about React's onClick event?

It uses camelCase notationIt uses lowercase notation

It uses camelCase notation.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a button that logs "Welcome to React!" on click.

Make sure to pick welcomeMessage, followed by onClick, and finally welcomeMessage.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the correct function to log "Hi there!".

Make sure to type handleClick.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the correct event handler for JSX.

Make sure to pick onClick.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
How should you pass the function displayMessage to an onClick event so that it's executed when clicking the button?

onClick={displayMessage}onClick=displayMessage()onClick="displayMessage"

Make sure to pick onClick={displayMessage}.
